comments.text:
If only it were this simple. The bankers don't control Iceland, the fishing 
industry does. Five years after the crash Icelanders voted the same parties 
into power that got us into this mess. The first thing they did was to 
repeal a law that would have had the fishing industry pay their fair share 
for the exclusive fishing rights that the government had previously handed 
to them for free. The last thing these parties did as while in opposition 
was, by filibustering and other creative time wasting measures, to block 
the primary passing of a new constitution (constitutional changes need to 
be passed by parliament twice, with an election taking place in the 
meantime). This was a constitution drawn up by citizens elected in a 
national election (for which people holding political office were 
ineligible to run), which would have given vastly greater powers to the 
general public and included a clause ensuring that common national 
resources (including the fish in the sea around Iceland) belonged to the 
general public. Now they're busy effectively raising taxes on the poor and 
alleviating tax on the super rich. Congratulations Iceland.﻿

comments.author: Elmithian

comments.text:
"For all the fearmongering we hear out of our politicians on the right 
about how heaven forbid we're going to turn into Greece, the one country 
you never hear them talk about any more is Iceland. The reason they don't 
is, as Cenk Uygur explained on his show this Tuesday, they took a different 
path than the United States after their financial crisis and nationalized 
the banks, threw some the people responsible for the crash in jail and 
bailed out the homeowners instead of worrying about only bailing out the 
banks. And now they're coming back and their economy is growing again...".﻿
comments.author: James “NaKi” Ferguson

comments.text:
If you want to look at a developed country's response to debt crisis and 
debt management look no further than Australia. The Global Financial Crisis 
was generally avoided in Australia for two reasons. 1. Tighter / stricter / 
more appropriate regulation of the Banking Industry processes (e.g. only 
lending to those with the capacity to pay back) and 2. The quick 
implementation of stimulus packages (widely criticised by the political 
opposition of the time) that got unemployed tradespersons working when 
there was no work. It cost 4 lives (hence the criticism), but saved 
thousands of families and the economy﻿
comments.author: grim1383

comments.text: That's it. I'm moving to Iceland.﻿
comments.author: Evening Sky

comments.text:
*Iceland Fixed Their Economy*

How? By jailing their prime minister - and the executives of the largest 
banks, charging them with and convicting them for the crimes they'd 
committed against the people. Then they forgave excessive debts for the 
general population. Now they're doing fine and have withdrawn their 
application to be part of the EU.

The US could do the same - if the government and election process wasn't 
completely corrupted.﻿
